label: Gregersen et al., 2017
novelty: Not with self-talk but with the sport
participants_description: A mix of men and women voluteers from undergraduate programs in physical education and sport science participated in this study. For participation, they received course credit.
note_2: Power analysis (G*Power 3.1.9.2) was used to calculate the number of participanrs required to achieve a minimum power of .80 based on the estimated effect size of .90 (using the effect size identified in the Hatzigeorgiadis et al., 2011 study). The decision to specify instructional cues rather than providing participants with choice was due to the novelty of the experimental task. As participants had no prior experience in the task, they would not know which words to use, and providing task- specific training would have introduced a learning effect. Nevertheless, the choice of the instructional cues was based on previous piloting with an independent group where alternative options were tested. The duration of each subtest was approximately 4 min.  After the completion of the two tests, a standard manipulation check protocol (Hatzigeorgiadis et al., 2014) regarding the use of self-talk was administered to participants of the experimental and the control groups to ensure the integrity of the experimental conditions.

label: Beneka et al., 2013
novelty: Not with self-talk but with the sport
participants_description: Participants included men and women: knee injured with meniscal tear followed meniscectomy (6 months ago) and considered active individuals because they had regular participation (once or twice per week) in at least one sport or physical activity. They reported that they participated in sports such as tennis, basketball, volleyball, soccer or walking. After their arthroscopic surgery, they underwent a typical physical therapy protocol (10 sessions) with the use of therapeutic modalities for range of motion improvement and strength enhancement. They did not undergo any treatment including a stability exercise programme, so the dynamic stability test was a novel task for them.

label: Galanis et al., 2018
novelty: Not with self-talk but with the sport
participants_description: Female basketball players with a mean age of 20.96 and sport experience of 9.21 years. They were from two teams competing at the second division of the National Championship.
note_2: Week 1 participants practiced using instructional self-talk cues (e.g., focus, rim); week 2 they practiced using motivational self-talk cues (e.g., it’s in, count it); weeks 3 and 4 they practiced using combinations of instructional and motivational self-talk; finally weeks 5 and 6 they developed their own free-throw self-talk plan for the final assessment.

note_2: A-priori power analysis was performed for sample size calculation using GPower 3.1. According to the previous study that used a similar research design (Blanchfield et al., 2014), we imputed the following values, alpha = .05, power = .80, the effect size f = 0.35.
